message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fluoxetine is an SSRI antidepressant that can cause anorgasmia as one of its side effects. Option B is incorrect as fluoxetine has been shown to be safe in pregnancy with careful monitoring. Option C is also incorrect as fluoxetine can increase levels of concurrent neuroleptics. Option D is also incorrect as most side effects tend to diminish over time with continued use.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fluoxetine is an SSRI antidepressant that can cause anorgasmia as a side effect. Option (B) is incorrect since fluoxetine is a category C drug during pregnancy and can be used in certain situations. Option (C) is incorrect since fluoxetine does not decrease levels of concurrent neuroleptics. Option (D) is incorrect since many side effects of fluoxetine tend to resolve over time with continued use.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fluoxetine belongs to a class of antidepressants called selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), which often cause sexual side effects such as anorgasmia. Fluoxetine is considered safe to take during pregnancy, but it should be tapered off gradually to avoid withdrawal symptoms. It does not decrease levels of neuroleptics and some side effects may decrease over time as the patient adjusts to the medication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fluoxetine is an SSRI and can cause anorgasmia. It is also unsafe to take during pregnancy as it may cause harm to the developing fetus. It does not decrease levels of neuroleptics and while some side effects may persist, many may diminish over time. Therefore, option (A) is the correct statement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fluoxetine is an SSRI, which can cause anorgasmia as a side effect. It is also unsafe to take during pregnancy as it increases the risk of congenital malformations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fluoxetine is an SSRI, which can cause sexual dysfunction such as anorgasmia. It is also not safe to take during pregnancy as it can harm the fetus. It does not decrease levels of concurrent neuroleptics, and not all side effects persist throughout therapy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fluoxetine is an SSRI and can cause anorgasmia as a side effect. It is also generally considered safe to take during pregnancy, but the patient should discuss with her healthcare provider before making any changes to her medication regimen. It does not decrease levels of concurrent neuroleptics, and while some side effects may persist throughout therapy, many will resolve over time or with dosage adjustments.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fluoxetine is an SSRI antidepressant that can cause sexual dysfunction, including anorgasmia. It is generally considered safe to take during pregnancy but should be discussed with a healthcare provider. It does not decrease levels of concurrent neuroleptics and some side effects may improve or resolve with time or dosage adjustment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fluoxetine is an SSRI antidepressant that can cause sexual side effects such as anorgasmia. It is not safe to take during pregnancy due to potential risks to the fetus. It does not decrease levels of concurrent neuroleptics and most side effects may subside with continued use. It is important for the patient to discuss with their healthcare provider before discontinuing any medication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fluoxetine can cause anorgasmia and should be tapered off slowly if the patient wants to stop taking it. It is a pregnancy category C medication, which means there is no conclusive evidence of risk during pregnancy but the benefits vs. risks should be evaluated. It does not affect levels of concurrent neuroleptics and most side effects tend to subside over time.
